{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Jheronimus Bosch 003.jpg | title=Allegory of Intemperance | artist=Hieronymus Bosch | year=1490-1500 | height_metric= | width_metric= | height_imperial= | width_imperial= | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | museum= }} [[File:Triptyque du vagabond (reconstitution).jpg|thumb|right|A reconstruction of the left and right wings of the triptych: at upper left ''[[Ship of Fools (painting)|The Ship of Fools]]''; at lower left: ''Allegory of Gluttony and Lust''. Panel at right is ''Death and the Miser''. At bottom "The Wayfarer" which would have been on the outside of the triptych.]] '''''Allegory of Intemperance''''' is a [[Hieronymus Bosch]] painting made sometime between 1490 and 1500. It is currently in the [[Yale University Art Gallery]] in [[New Haven]], [[Connecticut]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hieronymus-bosch.org/Allegory-of-Gluttony-and-Lust.html|title=Allegory of Gluttony and Lust - Hieronymous Bosch|accessdate=11 March 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100419003453/http://www.hieronymus-bosch.org/Allegory-of-Gluttony-and-Lust.html| archivedate= 19 April 2010 | deadurl= no}} This panel is the left inside bottom wing of a hinged triptych. The other identified parts are [[Ship of Fools (painting)|''The Ship of Fools'']], which formed the upper left panel, and the ''[[Death and the Miser]]'', which was the right panel; ''[[The Wayfarer]]'' was painted on the right panel rear. The central panel, if existed, is unknown. The ''Allegory'' represented a condemnation of gluttony, in the same way the right panel condemned avarice.{{Cite web |url=http://artgallery.yale.edu/collections/objects/allegory-intemperance |title=Page at the museum's official website |access-date=2014-09-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140917021840/http://artgallery.yale.edu/collections/objects/allegory-intemperance |archive-date=2014-09-17 |dead-url=yes |df= }} The fragment shows a fat man riding a barrel in a kind of lake or pool. He is surrounded by other people, who push him or pour a liquid from the barrel. Below, a man swims with, above his head, a vessel with meat. The swimmer's clothes lie on the shore at bottom. On the right, under a hut, a couple is devoting to lascivious acts, perhaps induced by drunkenness. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20140917021840/http://artgallery.yale.edu/collections/objects/allegory-intemperance Page at the museum's official website]

archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091122160954/http://www.cic.gc.ca/english/pdf/pub/discover.pdf| archivedate=22 November 2009| deadurl=no}} or formally as the '''Arms of Her Majesty The Queen title=The Public Register of Arms, Flags and Badges of Canada, Vol. IV, p. 457| publisher=The Canadian Heraldic Authority| accessdate=1 December 2011}}{{cite web | url=http://www.tbs-sct.gc.ca/hgw-cgf/oversight-surveillance/communications/fip-pcim/index-eng.asp#toc3 | title=Federal Identity Program | publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada | accessdate=4 October 2016 | last=Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat | authorlink=Treasury Board Secretariat}}{{cite web| url=http://www.heraldry.ca/misc/coatArmsCanada.htm| title=The Coat of Arms of Canada – A Short History| publisher=Royal Heraldry Society of Canada| accessdate=28 June 2009| archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6547ogIP2?url=http://www.heraldry.ca/misc/coatArmsCanada.htm| archive-date=30 January 2012| dead-url=yes| df=dmy-all}}{{cite book| last=Tidridge| first=Nathan| title=Canada's Constitutional Monarchy: An Introduction to Our Form of Government| publisher=Dundurn Press| location=Toronto| page=71| year=2011| isbn=9781459700840| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JvGsvHsAtDgC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false}} is, since 1921, the official [[coat of arms]] of the [[Monarchy of Canada|Canadian monarch]] and thus also of [[Canada]].{{cite web | url=http://canadiancrown.gc.ca/eng/1396525887776 | title=Canadian Flags of the Royal Family | publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada | date=2 October 2014 | accessdate=9 December 2015 | author=Department of Canadian Heritage, Government of Canada | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160102234745/http://canadiancrown.gc.ca/eng/1396525887776 | archive-date=2 January 2016 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }} It is closely modelled after the [[royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom]] with French and distinctive Canadian elements replacing or added to those derived from the British version. The [[maple leaves]] in the shield, [[blazon]]ed "proper", were originally drawn [[Vert (heraldry)|vert]] (green) but were redrawn [[gules]] (red) in 1957 and a circlet of the [[Order of Canada]] was added to the arms for limited use in 1987. The shield design forms the [[Royal standards of Canada#Sovereign's standard|monarch's royal standard]] and is also found on the [[Canadian Red Ensign]]. The [[Flag of the Governor General of Canada]], which formerly used the shield over the [[Union Flag]], now uses the [[crest (heraldry)|crest]] of the arms on a blue field. The arms are embossed on the cover of any [[Canadian nationality law|citizen]]'s [[Canadian passport]], in order to legally signify and symbolize that the bearer is travelling under the aid of the [[The Crown#Concept|Crown of Canada]]. ==History== [[Image:Blason proposé pour la province royale de Canada en 1663.svg|thumb|left|150px|Blason proposed for the [[New France|French Province of Canada]] in 1663.]] Prior to [[Canadian Confederation|Confederation]] in 1867, the [[Royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom|Royal Arms of the United Kingdom]] served in Canada as the symbol of royal authority.{{cite web |url=http://www.heraldry.ca/misc/coatArmsCanada.htm |title=Royal Heraldry Society of Canada: The Coat of Arms |publisher=RHSC |date= |accessdate=8 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201192257/http://www.heraldry.ca/misc/coatArmsCanada.htm |archivedate=1 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} Arms had not been granted to any of the colonies in [[British North America]], apart from 17th-century grants to [[Coat of arms of Nova Scotia|Nova Scotia]]{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/atc-ac/ns_e.cfm |title=Canadian Symbols Promotion – Nova Scotia |publisher=Canadian Heritage |date=21 May 2008 |accessdate=21 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080925114721/http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/atc-ac/ns_e.cfm|archivedate=25 September 2008}} and [[Coat of arms of Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]].{{cite web|url=http://www.assembly.nl.ca/Legislation/sr/statutes/c20.htm|title=RSNL1990 CHAPTER C-20 – COAT OF ARMS ACT|year=2006|publisher=Earl G. Tucker, Queen's Printer|accessdate=6 September 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://www.heritage.nf.ca/facts3.html |title=Heraldry and Flags: Newfoundland and Labrador Heritage |publisher=Memorial University of Newfoundland |accessdate=6 September 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080402042016/http://www.heritage.nf.ca/facts3.html |archivedate=2 April 2008 }} The year after Confederation, arms were granted by Royal Warrant on May 26, 1868 to [[Coat of arms of Ontario|Ontario]],{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/atc-ac/on_e.cfm |title=Ceremonial and Canadian Symbols Promotion – Ontario |publisher=Canadian Heritage |date=24 September 2007 |accessdate=21 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081022064914/http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/atc-ac/on_e.cfm |archivedate=22 October 2008 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} [[Coat of arms of Quebec|Quebec]],{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/atc-ac/qc_e.cfm |title=Ceremonial and Canadian Symbols Promotion – Quebec |publisher=Canadian Heritage |date=21 May 2008 |accessdate=21 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080910013110/http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/atc-ac/qc_e.cfm|archivedate=10 September 2008}} [[Coat of arms of Nova Scotia|Nova Scotia]]{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.ns.ca/legislature/HOUSE_OF_ASSEMBLY/Symbols/coat.htm |title=Nova Scotia/Nouvelle-Ecosse – Coat-of-Arms/Le blason |publisher=Government of Nova Scotia |date= |accessdate=31 October 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081210064609/http://www.gov.ns.ca/legislature/HOUSE_OF_ASSEMBLY/Symbols/coat.htm| archivedate= 10 December 2008| deadurl= no}} (that Nova Scotia had been granted arms was forgotten, and it took until 1929 for the historic arms granted in the 17th century to be reinstated) and [[Coat of arms of New Brunswick|New Brunswick]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/atc-ac/nb_e.cfm |title=Canadian Symbols Promotion – New Brunswick |publisher=Canadian Heritage |date=24 September 2007 |accessdate=21 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080606145242/http://www.pch.gc.ca/PROGS/CPSC-CCSP/atc-ac/nb_e.cfm |archivedate=6 June 2008 }} In the Royal Warrant of 1868, Queen Victoria authorized the four arms of the first provinces to be quartered for use on the Great Seal of Canada and while this was not done for the first Great Seal, it is through this reference it became the ''de facto'' arms for Canada until 1921.{{cite book |title=Use of Non-Traditional Evidence: A case study using heraldry to examine competing theories for Canada’s Confederation |author=Bruce M. Hicks |year= 2010 |publisher= British Journal of Canadian Studies 43 (1), pp.87-117| issn=0269-9222}} That is why it was in this form Canada was represented on the first [[Canadian Red Ensign|Red Ensign]] carried by Canadian troops at Vimy Ridge in 1917. A shield of arms first quartered and then, over time, as more provinces and territories joined Canada, marshalled with the arms of the new members of Confederation emerged through popular and even Canadian governmental usage. This eventually resulted in a shield with nine quarterings, an arrangement that had never been approved by the monarch. Nine quarterings on a shield was considered too complex for a national symbol and by 1915 a push had begun to design a new coat of arms for Canada.{{cite book|last=Fraser|first=Alistair B|title=The Flags of Canada|date=30 January 1998|chapter=Chapter I, Canada's National Symbols|url=http://fraser.cc/FlagsCan/index.html|chapterurl=http://fraser.cc/FlagsCan/Nation/NatSym.html|accessdate=1 October 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080915061016/http://fraser.cc/FlagsCan/index.html| archivedate=15 September 2008| deadurl=no}} A committee was formed in 1919 to pursue the issue, eventually agreeing that the elements of the new arms would reference the Royal Arms of England, Ireland, Scotland, and France, with maple leaves representing Canada, though there was at the time no consensus on how the leaves were to be used. The decision was settled by 1920, and the committee conferred with the [[College of Arms]] in London, only to face resistance to the use of the Royal Arms from the [[Garter King of Arms]]. After some manoeuvring, including the personal intervention of [[Winston Churchill]], the new arms of Canada were eventually formally requested by an [[Order in Council]] on 30 April 1921 and adopted on 21 November of the same year by proclamation of King [[George V]] as the Arms or Ensigns Armorial of the Dominion of Canada.{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/sc-cs/arm1_e.cfm |title=Ceremonial and Canadian Symbols Promotion – The arms of Canada |publisher=Canadian Heritage |date=23 June 2008 |accessdate=21 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080924075037/http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/sc-cs/arm1_e.cfm|archivedate=24 September 2008}}{{London Gazette|issue=32525|page=9242|date=22 November 1921}} The new layout closely reflected the arms of the United Kingdom{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/sc-cs/arm2_e.cfm |title=Ceremonial and Canadian Symbols Promotion – The arms of Canada (page 2)|publisher=Canadian Heritage |date=23 June 2008 |accessdate=21 November 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080924072609/http://www.pch.gc.ca/PROGS/CPSC-CCSP/sc-cs/arm2_e.cfm |archivedate=24 September 2008}} with the addition of maple leaves in the base and the reference to the French royal arms in the fourth quarter.{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/sc-cs/symboles-histoire-symbols-stories/symbole_canada_symbols-eng.pdf|title=Symbols of Canada|year=2008|publisher=Canadian Heritage|accessdate=20 November 2008|page=6}} The proclamation also established white and red as the [[national colours of Canada]]. In 1931, with the passage of the Statute of Westminster, Canada and other Dominions became fully sovereign from the United Kingdom. This had the effect of elevating the Canadian coat of arms, which had been granted as deputed arms for particular uses in a colony, to the status of the royal arms of the King in right of the country, for general purposes throughout the country. They thus replaced the British coat of arms, which had previously been arms of general purpose throughout the British Empire, in court rooms and on government buildings to represent the ruling monarch. This change can be seen in the Great Seal of Canada of George VI, where the royal arms of Canada replaced the British arms, and is even more evident in the Great Seal of Canada for [[Elizabeth II]], where the title has been redefined as ''Queen of Canada''.{{cite book|last=Swann|first=Conrad|title=Canada Symbols of Sovereignty: An investigation of the arms and seals borne from the earliest times to the present in connection with public authority in and over Canada. along with consideration of some connected flags|chapter=Chapter I, Arms of dominion and sovereignty and public authority|location=Toronto|publisher= University of Toronto Press}} These are the coat of arms of the Queen of Canada. By 1957, the arms were redrawn by [[Alan Beddoe]] so as to have red leaves and to change the royal crown from one of a Tudor design to one more resembling [[St. Edward's Crown]], as preferred by Queen Elizabeth II. To mark the 1982 [[patriation]] of the Canadian constitution, which finally ended the last vestiges of British authority over Canada, a [[McGill University]] student named Bruce Hicks proposed to [[Secretary of State (Canada)|Secretary of State]] [[Gerald Regan]] that the motto of the [[Order of Canada]] be placed around the shield in order to bring these royal arms into line with other royal arms, many of which have been displayed in Canada during French, Scottish, and English colonisation, where those countries' highest national order of honour appears around the shield of the arms (the British arms displayed the [[Order of the Garter]], the Scottish [[Royal coat of arms of Scotland|royal arms]] the [[Order of the Thistle]], and the royalist [[National Emblem of France|arms of the French Regime]] the [[Order of the Holy Spirit]] and [[Order of Saint Michael]]).{{cite book|last=Hicks|first=Bruce|title=The Campaign to Change the Royal Arms of Canada (Hogtown Heraldry 12:4)}} While unsuccessful in this first attempt, Hicks continued his campaign and was joined by a number of other amateur and professional heraldists. As a journalist in the parliamentary press gallery in Ottawa in the late 1980s and early 90s, Hicks strategically recast the change as something worth doing to commemorate the 25th Anniversary of the Order of Canada in 1992, an idea that was endorsed by the Advisory Committee on the Order of Canada.{{cite book|last=McCreery|first=Christopher|title=The Order of Canada: Its Origins, History and Development|isbn=0-8020-3940-5|location=Toronto|publisher=University of Toronto Press}} It took until 1994 for the Queen to approve the new design for general use, though the [[Canadian Heraldic Authority]] began to allow for its limited use beginning in 1987, where the arms were used to represent the Queen personally on letters patent granting new arms for distinguished Canadians. These letters patent carried the shield from the royal arms along with the annulus behind the shield bearing the motto of the [[Order of Canada]]—''Desiderantes meliorem patriam''. As soon as royal approval was forthcoming, the full achievement was redesigned for use by the federal government within the [[Federal Identity Program]]. The present design of the arms of Canada was drawn by [[Cathy Bursey-Sabourin]], Fraser Herald at the Canadian Heraldic Authority.{{cite book|last=Canadian Heritage|title=The Arms of Canada (Ottawa: Government of Canada)}} In June 2008, Member of Parliament [[Pat Martin]] introduced a [[Motion (democracy)|motion]] into the [[House of Commons of Canada]] calling on the government to amend the coat of arms to incorporate symbols representing Canada's [[First Nations]], [[Inuit]], and [[Métis people (Canada)|Métis]] peoples.{{Cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/coat-of-arms-ignores-aboriginal-people-mp-says-1.748913 |title=Coat of arms ignores aboriginal people, MP say |date=20 June 2008 |publisher=CBC |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080622224734/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/manitoba/story/2008/06/20/coat-arms.html |archive-date=22 June 2008 |dead-url=no |access-date=20 June 2008}} ===Armorial evolution=== Coat of arms of Canada (1868).svg|1868 1905 Canadian coat of arms postcard.jpg|1905 File:Coat of arms of Canada (1921).jpg|1921 Coat of arms of Canada (1923).jpg|1923 Coat of Arms of Canada (1957).png|1957 Coat of arms of Canada.svg|1994 ==Use== [[File:Coats of arms of Canada on Currie Hall Mackenzie Building Royal Military College of Canada.JPG|thumb|Arms of Canada on [[Currie Hall]], [[Royal Military College of Canada]]]] [[File:1914 Canadian $5 gold reverse.jpg|thumb|A 1914 Canadian $5 coin, minted 1912–1914, featuring the 1868 version of the arms]] The arms of Canada are the arms of the sovereign and signify national sovereignty and ownership.{{cite book | title=Ceremonial and Procedural Handbook of Canada | publisher=Her Majesty the Queen in Right of Canada | year=2010 | pages=106}} They are used as a mark of authority by various government agencies and representatives, including the [[Prime Minister of Canada|prime minister]]{{cite web|url=http://pm.gc.ca/|title=Prime Minister of Canada / Premier ministre du Canada|publisher=Office of the Prime Minister|accessdate=1 October 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080930004739/http://pm.gc.ca/| archivedate= 30 September 2008| deadurl= no}} and [[Cabinet of Canada|Cabinet]],{{cite web|url=http://pm.gc.ca/eng/cabinet.asp |title=Prime Minister of Canada: The Ministry |publisher=Office of the Prime Minister |accessdate=1 October 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081002085203/http://pm.gc.ca/eng/cabinet.asp |archivedate=2 October 2008 |deadurl=yes }} and most [[Court system of Canada#Symbols|courts]], including the [[Supreme Court of Canada|Supreme Court]],{{cite web|url=http://www.scc-csc.gc.ca/|title=Supreme Court of Canada – Welcome Page |date=4 September 2008|publisher=[[Supreme Court of Canada]]|accessdate=1 October 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081009092236/http://www.scc-csc.gc.ca/| archivedate= 9 October 2008| deadurl= no}} as well as the [[Canadian Armed Forces]] and [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]].{{cite book| title=Canadian Forces Dress Instructions| publisher=Canadian Armed Forces| author=Canadian Forces Department of History and Heritage| year=2010| location=Ottawa}}{{cite web|url=http://www.forces.gc.ca/site/about/Insignia/arma_e.asp |title=National Defence and the Canadian Forces |publisher=Forces.gc.ca |date=30 October 2008 |accessdate=8 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080702084606/http://www.forces.gc.ca/site/About/Insignia/arma_e.asp |archivedate=2 July 2008 }}{{cite web| url=http://www.rcmp-grc.gc.ca/unif/badge-insigne-eng.htm#ranknonofficers| title=RCMP Badges and Insignia| publisher=Her Majesty the Queen of Canada as represented by the Minister of Public Safety| date=7 April 2014| accessdate=7 March 2016| author=Royal Canadian Mounted Police}} It is also present on all pre-polymer denominations of [[Banknotes of the Canadian dollar|Canadian banknotes]] (in fact, the way the arms were printed on each bill is a security feature),{{cite web|url=http://www.bankofcanada.ca/en/banknotes/education/pdf/91-b-l(01-08)_booklet_en.pdf |title=Check to Protect |publisher=Bank of Canada / Banque du Canada |accessdate=1 October 2008 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} as well as the [[50 cent piece (Canadian coin)|50¢ coin]],{{cite web|url=http://www.mint.ca |title=Royal Canadian Mint – Monnaie Royale Canadienne |publisher=Mint.ca |date= |accessdate=21 November 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081204011602/http://www.mint.ca/| archivedate= 4 December 2008| deadurl= no}} and on the cover of [[Canadian passport]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.pptc.gc.ca/pptc/specifications.aspx?lang=eng|title=Passport Canada: Features of the Passport|publisher=Passport Canada|accessdate=1 October 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090308035327/http://www.pptc.gc.ca/pptc/specifications.aspx?lang=eng|archivedate=8 March 2009|df=dmy-all}} Since 1962, a [[Heraldic flag#Banner|banner]] of the arms, [[Defacement (flag)|defaced]] with a variant of the [[Royal Cypher|Queen's cypher]], has formed the [[Royal standards of Canada|sovereign's standard for Canada]], for use by the Queen in her capacity as monarch of Canada.{{cite book|last=Fraser|first=Alistair B|title=The Flags of Canada|date=30 January 1998|chapter=Chapter II, Canada's Head of State|url=http://fraser.cc/FlagsCan/Nation/StateHead.html|accessdate=1 October 2008| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080917025446/http://www.fraser.cc/FlagsCan/Nation/StateHead.html| archivedate=17 September 2008| deadurl= no}} Since, six additional standards for use by other members of the [[Monarchy of Canada#Canada's royal family and house|Canadian Royal Family]] have been created. In the Canadian Armed Forces and Royal Canadian Mounted Police, the most senior non-commissioned ranks wear the 1957 version of the coat of arms as a badge of rank, representing the fact that they have received the Queen's warrant (as opposed |to the Queen's commission for officers). The revised 1957 and 1994 Arms of Canada are both protected official government symbols used to represent the state under the Federal Identity Program. Permanent resident cards issued from 2015 feature a holographic representation of the 1957 version of the coat of arms.{{cite web|url=http://www.cic.gc.ca/english/department/media/multimedia/video/pr-card/pr-card.asp=eng|title=Permanent Resident Card|publisher=Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada|accessdate=12 July 2017}}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The full achievement of the coat of arms has been used by the Canadian government on occasion on a plain red flag, such as in 1967 for [[Canadian Centennial|the country's centennial celebrations]].{{cite web| url= http://flagspot.net/flags/ca_coa.html | title = Canadian Coat of Arms flag| author= Flags of the World|date=February 2004| accessdate=14 April 2007}} It is also used on a flag in its full achievement in military ceremonies, such as Canadian Armed Forces Tattoo performances.{{cite web| url= http://regimentalrogue.tripod.com/blog/index.blog?topic_id=1129460 | title = The Minute Book| author= The News and Eastern Townships Advocate|date=25 May 1967|accessdate=15 May 2015}} The personal [[Flag of the Governor General of Canada|flag of the Governor General]] has, since 1981, featured the crest of the royal arms of Canada on a blue background.{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/sc-cs/o7_e.cfm|title=Ceremonial and Canadian Symbols Promotion – Personal Flags and Standards|publisher=Minister of Public Works and Government Services|accessdate=4 September 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080621163539/http://www.pch.gc.ca/PROGS/CPSC-CCSP/sc-cs/o7_e.cfm |archivedate=21 June 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://archive.gg.ca/heraldry/emb/index_e.asp|title=Symbols of the Governor General|publisher=Rideau Hall|accessdate=4 September 2008}} In response to a new campaign by Bruce Hicks for the Canadian Parliament to have a distinct heraldic symbols along the lines of the [[portcullis]] (variations of which are used by the Commons and Lords in the British Parliament),{{cite book|last=Hicks|first=Bruce|title= A ‘Call to Arms’ for the Canadian Parliament" (Canadian Parliamentary Review 23:4)}} a proposal that was supported by [[Speaker of the House of Commons of Canada|Speakers of the House of Commons]] [[John Allen Fraser|John Fraser]] and [[Gilbert Parent]], a Commons committee was eventually struck following a motion by MP Derek Lee, before which Hicks and [[Robert Watt]], the first [[Chief Herald of Canada]], were called as the only two expert witnesses, though Senator [[Serge Joyal]] joined the committee ex-officio on behalf of the Senate. Commons' Speaker{{cite web|url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/information/about/people/House/Speaker/index_e.html|title=The Speaker – House of Commons Canada – Welcome|publisher=Parliament of Canada|accessdate=1 October 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080928141122/http://www.parl.gc.ca/information/about/people/House/Speaker/index_e.html| archivedate= 28 September 2008| deadurl= no}} [[Peter Milliken]] then asked the Canadian Heraldic Authority to authorize such a symbol and, on 15 February 2008, the Governor General authorized the House of Commons to begin using a badge of the shield of the royal arms superimposed on the [[ceremonial mace]] assigned to the House of Commons as a symbol of the royal authority under which it operates.{{cite web|url=http://archive.gg.ca/heraldry/pub-reg/project.asp?lang=e&ProjectID=1246|title=Public Register of Arms- House of Commons|publisher=[[Governor General of Canada]]|accessdate=7 October 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www2.parl.gc.ca/Sites/LOP/Education/CanSymbols/galleries/parliament/hoc_mace-e.asp |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120919124424/http://www2.parl.gc.ca/Sites/LOP/Education/CanSymbols/galleries/parliament/hoc_mace-e.asp |dead-url=yes |archive-date=19 September 2012 |title=Library of Parliament – Canadian symbols at Parliament |accessdate=23 August 2010 }} Following the Commons example, the [[Senate of Canada|Senate]] then requested and obtained on 15 April 2008 a similar badge for itself with the shield of the royal arms surmounted on the mace assigned to the Senate.{{cite web|url=http://archive.gg.ca/heraldry/pub-reg/project.asp?lang=e&ProjectID=1283|title=Public Register of Arms- Senate|publisher=[[Governor General of Canada]]|accessdate=7 October 2010}} ==Blazon== The [[Heraldry|heraldic]] [[blazon]] of Canada's coat of arms, as declared in the 1921 proclamation, is:
Tierced in fesse the first and second divisions containing the quarterly coat following, namely, 1st, [[gules]] three lions passant guardant in [[pale (heraldry)|pale]] [[Or (heraldry)|Or]], 2nd, Or a lion rampant within a double tressure flory-counter-flory gules, 3rd, [[Azure (heraldry)|azure]] a harp Or stringed [[argent]], 4th, azure, three fleurs-de-lis Or, and the third division argent three maple leaves conjoined on one stem proper. And upon a royal helmet mantled argent doubled gules the crest, that is to say, on a wreath of the colours argent and gules a lion passant guardant Or imperially crowned proper and holding in the dexter paw a maple leaf gules. And for supporters on the dexter a lion rampant Or holding a lance argent, point Or, flying therefrom to the dexter the [[Union Flag]], and on the sinister a unicorn argent armed crined and unguled Or, gorged with a coronet composed of crosses-patée and fleurs-de-lis a chain affixed thereto reflexed of the last, and holding a like lance flying therefrom to the sinister a banner azure charged with three fleurs-de-lis Or; the whole ensigned with the Imperial Crown proper and below the shield upon a wreath composed of roses, thistles, shamrocks and lillies a scroll azure inscribed with the motto A mari usque ad mare.
The circlet of the [[Order of Canada]] was added around the shield for limited use in 1987, and for general use in 1994. ==Symbolism== {| class="wikitable noresize" |- ! Element ! Description ! Image |- ! Crown | The coat of arms are surmounted by a rendition of [[St. Edward's Crown]], which has been used in the [[coronation]]s of Canada's monarchs. This element represents Canada's status as a [[constitutional monarchy]] headed by a sovereign king or queen. This style of crown is that preferred by Queen Elizabeth II, and was modernized in 1957 from the 1921 design, which used the Tudor crown.{{-}} | [[File:Canadian Crown.svg|center|130x130px]] |- ! Crest | The [[crest (heraldry)|crest]] is based on the Royal Crest of the United Kingdom but differenced by the addition of a maple leaf, and symbolizes the sovereignty of Canada.{{cite web|url=http://archive.gg.ca/heraldry/emb/index_e.asp|title=Symbols of the Governor General|publisher=Rideau Hall|accessdate=21 November 2008}} It appears on the [[Flag of the Governor General of Canada|flag of the Governor-General]], symbolizing that the Governor General is a representative of the Sovereign. The crest consists of a crowned gold lion standing on a twisted [[Torse|wreath]] of red and white silk and holding a maple leaf in its right paw.{{-}} | [[File:Canadian Crest.svg|center|130x130px]] |- ! Helm | The arms show a royal [[Helmet#Heraldry|helmet]], which is a barred helm of gold embossed with a maple leaf design looking outward, with [[mantling]] of white and red, stylized in the official version to look like maple leaves. {{-}} | [[File:Canadian Helm.svg|center|130x130px]] |- ! Escutcheon | The [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|escutcheon]] is divided into five sections. The first [[Division of the field|division]] at the viewer's top left contains the three golden [[Lion (heraldry)|lions]] that have been a symbol of England since at least the reign of [[Richard I of England|King Richard I]].{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldica.org/topics/britain/royalarm.htm |title=Royal Arms of Britain |publisher=Heraldica.org |date= |accessdate=21 November 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081206035142/http://www.heraldica.org/topics/britain/royalarm.htm| archivedate= 6 December 2008| deadurl= no}} The second quarter bears the red lion [[charge (heraldry)|rampant]] of [[Scotland]] in a double tressure border with [[fleur-de-lis|fleurs-de-lis]], used as a symbol of Scotland since at least the reign of [[William I of Scotland|William I]]. The third quarter shows the [[Coat of arms of Ireland|Irish harp]] of [[Tara, Ireland|Tara]]. The gold fleurs-de-lis of royal France, the first post-[[Middle Ages|medieval]] European emblem raised in Canada by [[Jacques Cartier]], during his landing at Gaspé,{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldry.ca/top_en/top_historyHer.htm|title=The History of Heraldry in Canada|publisher=Royal Heraldry Society of Canada|date=28 April 2004|accessdate=21 August 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090306201754/http://www.heraldry.ca/top_en/top_historyHer.htm|archive-date=6 March 2009|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} fill the fourth quarter. The fifth [[Charge (heraldry)|charge]], a sprig of red [[maple]] leaves at the bottom, is a distinctly Canadian symbol that became gradually identified with the country throughout the 19th century.{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/sc-cs/symboles-histoire-symbols-stories/symbole_canada_symbols-eng.pdf|title=Symbols of Canada|year=2008|publisher=Canadian Heritage|accessdate=20 November 2008|page=9}} They were first proposed as a symbol in 1834, were established in 1868 on the arms of [[Quebec]] and [[Ontario]] and officially became the national emblem in 1965, with the proclamation of the [[Flag of Canada]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/PROGS/CPSC-CCSP/sc-cs/df7_e.cfm |title=Ceremonial and Canadian Symbols Promotion – You were asking |publisher=Canadian Heritage |date=24 September 2007 |accessdate=21 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080924102524/http://www.pch.gc.ca/progs/cpsc-ccsp/sc-cs/df7_e.cfm|archivedate=24 September 2008}} Initially, the leaves were depicted as coloured green on the coat of arms because it was thought to represent youth, as opposed to the red colour of dying leaves in autumn. However, they are blazoned as "proper", so could be shown as either red or green, and it is the blazon, rather than any depiction, which is regarded as authoritative. The leaves were later redrawn in official depictions in 1957 with the current colour to be in line with the official colours of Canada. They are further stylized in that natural maple leaves do not grow in sprigs of three. The shield forms the basis of the [[Queen's Personal Canadian Flag|royal standard of Canada]]. | [[File:Canadian Coat of Arms Shield.svg|center|130x130px]] |- ! Ribbon | The ribbon is marked ''desiderantes meliorem patriam'', meaning "desiring a better country," which is the motto of the [[Order of Canada]], taken from [[Epistle to the Hebrews|Hebrews]] 11:16. This component was added by the Queen in 1987 on the [[Advice (constitutional)|advice]] of her [[Brian Mulroney|Prime Minister]]. With the patriation of oversight of arms to Canada through the [[Canadian Heraldic Authority]] the following year,{{cite web|url=http://archive.gg.ca/heraldry/cha/index_e.asp|title=The Canadian Heraldic Authority|publisher=Canadian Heraldic Authority|date=27 September 2005 |origyear=updated 14 June 2006|accessdate=2 September 2008}} the constitution of the [[Order of Canada]] was amended to include entitlement by all recipients to encircle their own arms with the ribbon, if arms are granted to them.{{cite web|url=http://archive.gg.ca/honours/nat-ord/oc/oc-con_e.asp |title=The Constitution of the Order of Canada |publisher=[[Governor General of Canada]] |date=6 December 2005 |accessdate=21 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110530014527/http://archive.gg.ca/honours/nat-ord/oc/oc-con_e.asp |archivedate=30 May 2011 }} Since 1994 the arms used by government ministers and institutions have slowly changed to reflect the new version with the ribbon. | [[File:Order of Canada circlet (heraldry).svg|center|130x130px]] |- ! Motto | The [[motto]] of Canada is in Latin ''a mari usque ad mare'' (From sea to sea), a part of [[Psalms|Psalm]] 72:8.{{cite web|url=https://thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/a-mari-usque-ad-mare/ |title=A Mari usque ad Mare |last=Lamb |first=W. Kaye |work=The Canadian Encyclopedia |publisher=Historica Foundation of Canada |accessdate=21 November 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070817072335/http://thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=A1ARTA0000001 |archivedate=17 August 2007 |df=dmy }} This phrase was suggested by [[Joseph Pope (public servant)|Joseph Pope]], then-Under Secretary of State, when the Arms were redesigned in 1921. The motto was originally used in 1906 on the head of the mace of the [[Legislative Assembly of Saskatchewan]]. In March 2006, the premiers of Canada's [[Territories of Canada|three territories]] called for the amendment of the motto to better reflect the vast geographic nature of Canada's territory,{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/News/Ideas/article/271165 |title= Time to herald our northern coast?|date=28 October 2007 |author=Andrew Chung|accessdate=21 November 2008 | location=Toronto | work=The Star| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081013082850/http://www.thestar.com/News/Ideas/article/271165| archivedate= 13 October 2008| deadurl= no}} as Canada has coastlines on the [[Arctic Ocean|Arctic]], [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]], and [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]] Oceans. Two suggestions for a new motto are ''A mari ad mare ad mare'' (from sea to sea to sea) and ''A mari usque ad maria'' (from the sea to the other seas).{{cite news |last=Deveau |first=Scott |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20060309.wmotto0309/BNStory/National/home |title=From sea to sea to sea |publisher=Theglobeandmail.com |date=3 September 2006 |accessdate=21 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6547u6u8q?url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/subscribe.jsp?art=815507 |archivedate=30 January 2012 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news|author=CBC News |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2006/03/10/northern-motto060310.html |title='To sea' or not 'to sea': that is the question |publisher=Cbc.ca |date= 10 March 2006|accessdate=21 November 2008}} | [[File:Canadian Motto.svg|center|130x130px]] |- ! Supporters | [[Supporters|Supporting]] the shield on either side are the English lion and Scottish [[unicorn]], which are also the supporters of the [[Royal Coat of Arms of the United Kingdom|UK coat of arms]]. The English lion stands on the viewer's left and holds a gold-pointed silver lance flying the [[Union Flag]]. The Scottish unicorn has a gold horn, a gold mane, gold hooves, and around its neck a gold, chained [[coronet]] of crosses and fleurs-de-lis; it holds a lance flying the three gold fleurs-de-lis of royal France on a blue background. Unlike the British version, the lion is not crowned, nor is it facing the viewer. The broken chain on the unicorn symbolizes the unicorn's resistance to oppression. | [[File:CcoasupportersB.JPG|center|130x130px]] |- ! Compartment | The entire coat of arms rests on the [[Compartment (heraldry)|compartment]], which is made up of the floral emblems of the founding nations. The [[Tudor rose]] is the floral badge of England and Wales, combining the [[White Rose of York]] and the [[Red Rose of Lancaster]]. The [[thistle]] and [[shamrock]] are the symbols of Scotland and Ireland, respectively, while the [[fleur-de-lis]] has been the royal symbol of France since the 12th century.{{cite book|last=Lewis|first=Philippa|author2=Darley, Gillian|title=Dictionary of Ornament|publisher=Pantheon|year=1986|isbn=978-0394509310}} | [[File:Canadian Compartment.svg|center|130x130px]] |} ==Legal== As the Royal Arms are personal to the sovereign they cannot be used without consent.{{cite web | url=http://canadiancrown.gc.ca/eng/1396461395578 | title=Royal arms and insignia | publisher=Her Majesty the Queen in Right of Canada | date=1 June 2012 | accessdate=20 January 2014 | author=Government of Canada}} The coat of arms "as designed in 1921 and revised in 1957...(and) in 1994" are "protected under the ''Trade-marks Act'' and the ''Copyright Act'' and cannot be used or reproduced without authorization".{{cite web | url=http://www.tbs-sct.gc.ca/fip-pcim/spec/T105-eng.asp | title=Legal Protection (Canada) | publisher=Her Majesty the Queen in Right of Canada | date=10 May 2012 | accessdate=23 April 2015 | author=Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat (Government of Canada)}} Further, "Marks and designs similar to the official symbols are pursued as a copyright or trade-mark infringement". The ''Trade-marks Act'' further states that "No person shall adopt in connection with a business, as a trade-mark or otherwise, any mark consisting of, or so nearly resembling as to be likely to be mistaken for... the arms, crest or flag adopted and used at any time by Canada".{{Cite canlaw|short title= Trade-marks Act|abbr= R.S.C.|year= 1985|chapter= T-13|section= 9|subsection= 1(e)|link= http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/T-13/page-3.html#docCont|linkloc= Department of Justice Canada|wikilink= Canadian trade-mark law}} In addition, under Crown copyright, "permission is always required when the work is being revised, adapted, or translated regardless if the purpose of the reproduction is for personal or public non-commercial distribution".{{cite web|url=http://www.publications.gc.ca/site/eng/ccl/aboutCrownCopyright.html |title=About Crown Copyright |publisher=Government of Canada Publications |date=5 March 2013 |accessdate=1 July 2013 |author=Her Majesty the Queen in Right of Canada |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130604180718/http://publications.gc.ca/site/eng/ccl/aboutCrownCopyright.html |archivedate=4 June 2013 }} ==See also== {{Wikipedia books|Canada}} *[[Flag of Canada]] *[[List of Canadian provincial and territorial symbols]] *[[Great Seal of Canada]] *[[National symbols of Canada]] *[[Gallery of {{Infobox book | name = Art Deco Architecture: Design, Decoration and Detail from the Twenties and Thirties | author = Patricia Bayer | illustrator = | image = Art deco architecture -- bookcover.jpg | caption = Hardcover edition | published = October 1992 | subject = [[History of art]]
[[Art Deco architecture]] | genre = Non-fiction | publisher = [[Harry N. Abrams]] | country = United States | language = English | media_type = Print | isbn = 978-0810919235 | dewey = | congress = | oclc = 25509002 | pages = 224 pp. | website = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Art Deco Architecture: Design, Decoration and Detail from the Twenties and Thirties''''' is an illustrated book by American art historian Patricia Bayer. The book was initially published in October 1992 by [[Harry N. Abrams]].{{cite web|title=Art Deco Architecture: Design, Decoration and Detail from the Twenties and Thirties|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/0810919230|website=[[Amazon.com]]|publisher=amazon.com|accessdate=23 October 2015}}{{cite web|title=Art Deco Architecture: Design, Decoration, and Detail from the Twenties and Thirties by Patricia Bayer|url=http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/645062.Art_Deco_Architecture?from_search=true&search_version=service|website=[[Goodreads]]|publisher=goodreads.com|accessdate=23 October 2015}}{{cite web|title=Art Deco(ration)|url=http://thewalkupblog.com/category/home-decor/page/20/|publisher=thewalkupblog.com|accessdate=23 October 2015|date=3 June 2012}} Patricia Bayer is an art historian living in Connecticut and writing extensively on Art Deco design. Her other books include ''Art Deco Interiors'' and ''Art Deco Postcards''.{{cite web|title=Patricia Bayer|url=http://books.wwnorton.com/books/Author.aspx?id=18352|website=[[W. W. Norton & Company]]|publisher=books.wwnorton.com|accessdate=23 October 2015}} The book contains 376 Illustrations, 146 in colour.{{cite web|title=Art Deco Architecture: Design, Decoration and Detail from the Twenties and Thirties by Patricia Bayer|url=http://www.thamesandhudson.com/Art_Deco_Architecture/9780500281499|publisher=[[thamesandhudson.com]]|accessdate=23 October 2015}} ==Content== # Introduction # Influences, Precursors and Parallels # International Expositions # Residences and Hotels # Public Buildings, Office Buildings, Factories, Stores, Restaurants, Cinemas, Theatres, Travel Buildings, Civic Structures, Churches and Monuments # Revivals and Replicas ==Review== {{quote|From a sleekly modern apartment house in Cairo to a town hall in the Netherlands, architecture was influenced internationally by the Art Deco style, as revealed by this wide-angled, superbly illustrated survey. Bayer (The Art of Rene Lalique) first uncovers Art Deco's ancient and exotic sources, from Assyrian to Mayan to Moorish. Her text, wedded to 376 jazzy, snazzy illustrations (146 in color), demonstrates how this vibrant, decorative style extended between the wars into every nook and cranny of the U.S. leaving its mark on skyscrapers, movie theaters, firehouses, factories, dams, tunnels, high schools, gas stations, roadside diners and even gravestones. Bayer also examines the Art Deco revival, citing restored Miami Beach hotels as well as public buildings by [[Michael Graves]], [[Robert Venturi]] and [[Helmut Jahn]] that echo or evoke Art Deco, a style "at once traditional and innovative."}} —''[[Publishers Weekly]]''{{cite web|title=Art Deco Architecture: Design, Decoration, and Detail from the Twenties and Thirties|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-0-8109-1923-5|website=[[Publishers Weekly]]|publisher=publishersweekly.com|accessdate=23 October 2015}} ==See also== {{Category see also | Art Deco architecture | Art Deco ships | Art Deco sculptures and memorials | Art Deco games | Art Deco architects | Art Deco artists | Art Deco designers | Art Deco sculptors}} * ''[[Art Deco of the 20s and 30s]]'' * [[International style (architecture)|International style]] * [[List of Art Deco architecture]] * [[Paris architecture of the Belle Époque]] * ''[[The New York Apartment Houses of Rosario Candela and James Carpenter]]'' * ''[[Higher: A Historic Race to the Sky and the Making of a City]]'' ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://books.google.com/books?id=TeVPAAAAMAAJ&q=Art+Deco+Architecture:+Design,+Decoration+and+Detail+from+the+Twenties+and+Thirties&dq=Art+Deco+Architecture:+Design,+Decoration+and+Detail+from+the+Twenties+and+Thirties&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y Profile of Google Books] *{{youtube|dueU5vm5PwQ|A Brief History of Art Deco}} [[Category:American art]] [[Category:1992 books]] [[Category:History books]] [[Category:Art Deco]]

{{Infobox religious building | building_name=Basilica of the Holy Blood
Heilig-Bloedbasiliek {{nl icon}}
Basilique du Saint-Sang {{fr icon}} | image=Basilica of the Holy Blood - Saint-Baselius Chapel, Bruges, Belgium..jpg | caption= | location= {{flagicon|Belgium}}[[Bruges]], [[Belgium]] | geo = {{coord|51|12|29.4|N|3|13|36.2|E|region:BE_type:landmark |display=inline,title}} | religious_affiliation=[[Roman Catholic]] | rite= | province= | district= | consecration_year= | status=[[Minor basilica]] | leadership= [[Canon (priest)|Canon]] Libert Bruneel{{cite journal|date=2001-09-24|title=Nieuwe rector voor Bloedbasiliek |journal=[[Het Nieuwsblad]]|language=Dutch|url=http://www.nieuwsblad.be/Article/Detail.aspx?articleID=nbra24092001_030}} | website= [http://www.holyblood.com/ Official Website] | architect= | architecture_type= [[Church (building)|Church]] | architecture_style= [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]], [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] | heritage_designation = | facade_direction= NE | groundbreaking = 1134{{cite book|last=Snauwaert|first=Livia|title=Gids voor architectuur in Brugge|publisher=Lannoo Uitgeverij|location=Tielt|year=2005|pages=58–60|isbn=90-209-4711-7|url=https://books.google.com/?id=MiluvpH6yf0C&pg=PA59|language=Dutch}} | year_completed= 1157 | construction_cost= | specifications= no | capacity= | length= | width= | width_nave= | height_max= | materials= }} The '''Basilica of the Holy Blood''' ({{lang-nl|Heilig-Bloedbasiliek}}, {{lang-fr|Basilique du Saint-Sang}}) is a [[Roman Catholic]] [[basilica]] in [[Bruges]], [[Belgium]]. The church houses a venerated relic of the [[Blood of Christ|Holy Blood]] allegedly collected by [[Joseph of Arimathea]] and brought from the [[Holy Land]] by [[Thierry of Alsace]], [[Count of Flanders]]. Built between 1134 and 1157 as the [[chapel]] of the [[Count of Flanders]], it was promoted to a [[minor basilica]] in 1923. The basilica in Burg square consists of a lower and upper chapel. The lower chapel, dedicated to [[St. Basil the Great]], is a dark [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] structure that remains virtually unchanged. The venerated relic is in the upper chapel, which was rebuilt in the [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] style in the 16th century and renovated in the 19th century in [[Gothic Revival]] style. == History == In 1134, Thierry of Alsace decided to build a private double chapel next to the ''{{lang|nl|Oud Steen}}'', the first residence of the Counts of Flanders, transformed today into the [[town hall]] of Bruges. Thierry went on crusade a second time in 1147 during the [[Second Crusade]]. According to the tradition, Thierry of Alsace returned to his capital Bruges on April 7, 1150, with the relic of the [[Blood of Christ|Precious Blood]]. During the first half of the 13th century, the name of the upper chapel was changed to the Chapel of the Holy Blood. == St Basil chapel == [[File:Bruges - Holy Blood church.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Romanesque St Basil chapel]] The chapel of Saint Basil is one of the best preserved churches in Romanesque style of [[West-Flanders]]. Built from 1134 to 1149, the chapel is dedicated to [[St. Basil the Great]] of whom a relic was brought back by Count [[Robert II, Count of Flanders|Robert II]] from [[Caesarea Mazaca]] in [[Cappadocia]], [[Asia Minor]] (modern-day [[Turkey]]). The chapel consists of two side naves and a central nave continued by the choir, which in turn is ended by a semi-circular [[apse]]. In the [[Tympanum (architecture)|tympanum]] above the entrance linking the chapel and the annex is a 12th-century representation of the baptism of Saint Basil. In the right nave, the ''seated Madonna and Child'' (''[[Sedes Sapientiae]]'') is a wooden polychrome sculpture of the early 14th century. Carried each year during the procession, two venerated wooden statues, made around 1900 and representing ''Jesus on the Cold Stone'' and the ''Pieta'' are displayed. At the left of the choir, the chapel of Saint Yves was added in 1504 and houses the relics of Saint Basil and of Blessed [[Charles the Good]], Count of Flanders. The black marble retable is allegedly executed from designs by [[Lancelot Blondeel]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} == Chapel of the Holy Blood == Originally built in Romanesque style like the St Basil chapel, the upper chapel was transformed in Gothic Style at the end of the 15th century and again in 1823. Only the curved arches giving access to the side chapel of the Holy Cross remain from the original Romanesque chapel. [[File:Main altar of the Basilica of the Holy Blood.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Main altar of the Basilica of the Holy Blood.]] The monumental staircase, commonly named ''{{lang|nl|De Steegheere}}'', which leads to the upper chapel, was built in from 1529 to 1533 in late Gothic and Renaissance style according to the drawings of Flemish painter and architect [[Lancelot Blondeel|William Aerts]],{{cite journal|last=Weale|first=W. H. James|year=1908|title=Lancelot Blondeel-I|journal=[[The Burlington Magazine|The Burlington Magazine for Connoisseurs]]|volume=14|issue=68|pages=96–101|issn=0007-6287}} ornamented on the outside with sculpted statues. The aftermath of the French Revolution left the staircase badly damaged and it was decided in 1832 to move it {{convert|4|m}} backwards and to rebuild it after removing the remaining ruins of the ''Oud Steen''.It is considered to be the first artistic renovation carried out by the recently created [[Belgium|Belgian State]]. The gilded bronze statues represent Archduchess [[Isabelle of Burgundy]], [[Mary of Burgundy]], Thierry of Alsace and [[Philip of Alsace]] and, in the medallions, the Archdukes of Austria [[Albert VII, Archduke of Austria|Albert VII]] and [[Maximilian III of Austria|Maximilian III]], [[Margaret of York]] and [[Sibylla of Anjou]], wife of Thierry and daughter of King [[Fulk of Jerusalem]]. During the 19th century, successive renovation campaigns gave to the chapel its final [[Gothic Revival]] aspect, with its characteristic mural decorations. The stained-glass windows in the choir date from 1845The original stained-glass windows were removed after the [[French Revolution]]. Some of the original ones ended up in the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]] in London. and represent the sovereigns who reigned over the County of Flanders from [[Philip the Bold]], [[duke of Burgundy]], till Archduchess [[Maria Theresa of Austria]], [[Holy Roman emperor|Holy Roman empress]]. The following architects and artists took part in these [[neo-Gothic]] renovations of the Chapel of the Holy Blood: * [[Jean-Baptiste Bethune (architect)|Jean-Baptiste Bethune]] * [[Louis Delacenserie]] * [[Thomas Harper King]] * [[William Curtis Brangwyn]], father of [[Frank Brangwyn]] * [[Charles De Wulf]], architect of the city of Bruges and winner of the [[Prix de Rome]] in 1887{{cite web |title=Charles De Wulf |url=http://archief.oostende.be/product/91/default.aspx?_vs=0_N&id=5078 |publisher=Stad Oostende - Stadsarchief |location=Oostende |language=Dutch |accessdate=16 April 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090531064237/http://archief.oostende.be/product/91/default.aspx?_vs=0_N&id=5078| archivedate= 31 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} The pulpit in the form of a globe dates was made in 1728 by [[Henry Pulinckx]], inspired by its evangelical purpose : "''Go into all the world and preach the gospel''" {{bibleverse||Mark|16:15|NIV|}}. The large wall-painting behind the high altar was realized in 1905. In the upper part, the ''Mystery of the Cross'' depicts Christ shedding his blood, with, in the background, the towns of Bethlehem, where Christ was born, and Jerusalem where he died. The lower part depicts the transport of the relic from Jerusalem to Bruges: on the left, Thierry of Alsace receives the relic from [[Baldwin III of Jerusalem]], King of Jerusalem ; on the right, kneeling besides Countess [[Sibylla of Anjou]], he hands over the relic to the chaplain. The high altar used today for the Eucharist is decorated with a relief in alabaster from the beginning of the 17th century depicting the Last Supper. Typical attributes of a basilica, the [[tintinnabulum]], the small processional bell, and the [[Umbraculum]], the sunscreen in the form of a parasol in yellow and red silk, are displayed next to the high altar. [[Laurent Delvaux]] completed in 1751 the white marble altar in Baroque style for the relic side chapel. The two adoring angels were made by [[Peter Pepers]]. The relic is kept in a magnificent silver tabernacle made by local silversmith François Ryelandt (1709–1774), representing the "[[Lamb of Christ]]". To the right of the altar, the painting of [[Jacob van Oost]] depicts the descent from the Cross. The relic is shown to the public every Friday and every day two weeks before Ascension Day. == Relic of the Precious Blood == [[File:The Blood Relic.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Relic of the [[Blood of Christ|Holy Blood]], [[Bruges]].]] The basilica is best known as the repository of a venerated [[phial]] said to contain a cloth with blood of [[Jesus Christ]], brought to the city by Thierry of Alsace after the 12th century [[Second Crusade]]. Although the Bible never mentions Christ's blood being preserved, one of the [[apocryphal gospels]] asserts that [[Joseph of Arimathea]] preserved the [[Precious Blood]] after he had washed the dead body of Christ. The daily making present of the [[Blood of Christ]] during the [[Mass (liturgy)|Mass]] was central in the religious life of the [[Middle Age]] in Europe. If genuine, a relic of the Blood of Jesus would be of utmost significance, a uniquely important witness to Jesus’ Passion and a perpetual reminder of the historical character of the Christian Gospel. Popular legend asserts that the phial was taken to Bruges during the [[Second Crusade]] of [[Common Era|CE]] 1147–1149, by Thierry of Alsace, who returned from Jerusalem with the relic of the [[Blood of Christ|Holy Blood]] presented to him by his brother-in-law [[Baldwin III of Jerusalem]], as the reward of his great services.{{cite book | last = Nickell | first = Joe | title = Relics of the Christ | chapter=Blood of Jesus|publisher = University Press of Kentucky | location = Lexington | year = 2007 | isbn = 0-8131-2425-5|url=https://books.google.com/?id=A9sj9XmdmekC&pg=PA169|pages=169–170}} However, recent research found no evidences of the presence of the relic in Bruges before the 1250s. In all likelihood, the relic originated from the 1204 [[sack of Constantinople]] by the army of the [[Counts of Flanders|Count of Flanders]], [[Baldwin I of Constantinople|Baldwin IX]] during the [[Fourth Crusade]].{{cite book | last = Vincent | first = Nicholas | title = The Holy Blood: King Henry III and the Westminster Blood relic | publisher = [[Cambridge University Press]] | location = Cambridge | year = 2001 | isbn = 0-521-57128-6|url=https://books.google.com/?id=H8F28cKVdwAC&pg=PA73|page=73}} Ever since, the phial has played no small part in the religious life of the city.{{CathEncy| wstitle=Bruges| title =Bruges| first = Cyril| last = J.| authorlink = | accessdate =2009-01-07}} [[Pope Clement V]] issued a [[papal bull]] in 1310 granting [[indulgences]] to pilgrims who visited the chapel to view the relic. Recent investigations have showed that the phial, made of rock crystal and dating back to the 11th or 12th century, was a Byzantine perfume bottle made in the area of [[Constantinople]]. It was never opened since its arrival in Bruges. Its neck is wound with gold thread and its stopper is sealed with red wax. The phial is encased in a glass-fronted gold cylinder closed at each end by [[coronets]] decorated with angels. The date "''MCCCLXXXVIII die III maii''" (May 3, 1388) is engraved on the frame. == Procession of the Holy Blood == {{main article|Procession of the Holy Blood}} The reliquary used during the procession is displayed in the Basilica Museum. The shrine was made in 1617 in Bruges by [[goldsmith]] [[Jan Crabbe]] from some {{convert|30|kg|lb}} of gold and silver and more than 100 precious stones. It consists of a gem-encrusted hexagonal case topped by golden statues representing Jesus-Christ, The [[Virgin Mary]], [[Saint Donatian|St. Donatian]] and [[St. Basil the Great]]. ==Jeu du Saint Sang== ''Jeu du Saint Sang'' is a [[Belgium|Belgian]] [[passion play]], performed in [[Bruges]].{{cite web |url=http://www.hotelara.com/belgium/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120905073629/http://www.hotelara.com/belgium/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-09-05 |title=Belgium travel guide |publisher=Hotelara |date= |accessdate=2013-05-23 }} It was first published in 1938, and translated into French by [[Émile Schwartz]].Joseph Boon, ''Sanguis Christi, Le jeu du Saint Sang de Bruges'', in three acts and a prologue, French translation Émile Schwartz, éd. Renouveau « La Source », Bruxelles, 1947. == In popular culture == In the 2008 movie ''[[In Bruges]]'',{{IMDb title|0780536|Memorable quotes for [[In Bruges]]}} [[Brendan Gleeson]] as Ken pays a visit to the relic of the Holy Blood. However, the privately owned Church of Jerusalem ({{lang-nl|Jerusalemkerk}})—built in the 15th century according to the plans of the [[Holy Sepulcher]] in Jerusalem—was used instead of the Basilica. ==Gallery== File:Basilica of the Holy Blood.jpg|Detail of the entrance of the Basilica File:Gold Work Above Entrance.jpg|Detail of the [[staircase]] leading to Basilica of the Holy Blood File:Heilig Bloed Basiliek - Glasramen.JPG|Stained glass windows in the staircase File:Side Altar with Relic - Basilica Holy Blood - Bruges.jpg|Chapel of the Holy Cross where Relic of the Precious Blood is presented to the worshippers. |[[:nl:Juan Perez de Malvenda| Juan Perez de Maluenda]] digs out the Relic of the Holy Blood, stained glass window in the Chapel of the Holy Cross File:Relic of the Holy Blood - Brugges.jpg|Relic of the Holy Blood, carried during the [[Procession of the Holy Blood]] File:Brugge-staircase.jpg|Basilica of the Holy Blood staircase File:Chapel of the holy blood large window.jpg|Large stained glass window in the Chapel of the Holy Blood. File:Chapel of the holy blood small window.jpg|Chapel of the Holy Blood small stained glass window. == See also == * [[Saint Longinus]] == Notes == {{reflist|2}} == References == * {{cite book|last=Snauwaert|first=Livia|title=Gids voor architectuur in Brugge|publisher=Lannoo Uitgeverij|location=Tielt|year=2005|pages=58–60|isbn=90-209-4711-7|url=https://books.google.com/?id=MiluvpH6yf0C&pg=PA59|language=Dutch}} * {{Catholic| wstitle=Bruges| first = John Cyril| last =Weale| authorlink = | accessdate =7 January 2009}} == External links == {{Commons category|Basilica of the Holy Blood - Bruges}} * [http://www.holyblood.com Official website of the Procession of the Holy Blood ] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080626015018/http://www.trabel.com/brugge/bruges-holyblood.htm Bruges: The Chapel of the Holy Blood] at trabel.com * [http://www.frommers.com/destinations/bruges/A6338.html Heilig-Bloedbasiliek] at [[Frommers]] [[Category:Basilica churches in Belgium]] [[Category:Medieval architecture]] [[Category:Roman Catholic churches in Bruges]] [[Category:Relics associated with Jesus]] [[Category:Gothic architecture in Belgium]] [[Category:Romanesque architecture in Belgium]] [[Category:12th-century Roman Catholic church buildings]] [[Category:Double chapels]] [[Category:Churches used by the Priestly Fraternity of St. Peter]]

[[File:3x5 Basket Weave Knot.png|thumb|right|350px|A diagram of a basket weave knot on a 3x5 rectangular grid]] The '''basket weave knots''' are a family of [[bend (knot)|bend]] and [[lanyard]] [[knot]]s with a regular pattern of over–one, under–one. All of these knots are rectangular and lie in a plane.<ref name="ashley1">{{cite book |last= Ashley |first= Charles |title= The Ashley Book of Knots |pages= 139–140}}{{full|date=June 2014|reason=year, etc.}}</ref> They are named after [[braid|plait]]-woven [[basket weaving|baskets]], which have a similar appearance.
==Construction== [[File:2x5 Basket Weave Knot.png|thumb|left|A diagram of a long basket weave knot on a 2x5 grid]] A basket weave knot is made up of two sets of parallel lines drawn inside a rectangle such that the lines meet at the edges of the rectangle. For a true basket weave knot that can be tied with two strands, the number of intersections in each direction cannot have a common [[divisor]]. Within this constraint, there is no theoretical upper limit to the size of a basket weave knot.<ref name="ashley1"/> Thus, a knot that has two intersections in one direction can be lengthened with any odd number in the perpendicular direction. If the dimension ''n'' in the smaller direction is odd, it is always possible to construct a knot with ''n'' + 2 intersections in the other dimension. However, large basket weave knots have a tendency to twist and curl because they are completely flat.<ref name="ashley1"/>
A basket weave knot can be tied from a single strand by first forming a [[bight (knot)|bight]] in the middle of the line. The ends near the bight become the standing ends. This method will keep the knot in one plane only for knots in which the standing ends enter the same side; these knots are called ''[[bosun]]'s knots'' because they can be tied in a lanyard.<ref name="ashley1"/> For knots in which the standing ends enter from different sides of the rectangle, the bight will wrap across one side of the knot after it is set.
Any basket weave knot that can be tied from two strands can be drawn as an [[endless knot]] by connecting the standing ends together and the working ends together. An example of this can be seen in the [[carrick mat]].
[[File:Gosforth Cross Víðarr.jpg|right|thumb|A decorative use on the [[Gosforth Cross]], from the 10th century AD]] If a basket weave knot is tied with a flat line such as ribbon instead of a round line such as rope or cord, the method of turning the line at the edges affects the final appearance. Deflecting the line will form a series of bights or scallops along the edge, while folding it over will leave the edge flat.<ref name="ashley2">Ashley, pp. 148-149</ref>
==Examples== [[File:Carrick bend with basket weave grid.jpg|thumb|right|A [[carrick bend]] knot with a 2x3 rectangular grid superimposed upon it]] The simplest basket weave knots consist of a two–by–three rectangle of intersections and include the following:
*[[Carrick bend]] *[[Double coin knot]] *[[Sheet bend]] *[[Reef knot]] *[[Granny knot]]
In the reef knot and granny knot, the standing ends enter the short side, while in the double coin knot and the sheet bend, the standing ends enter the long side. Therefore, any of these knots could be used for a lanyard. In the carrick bend, which is otherwise similar to the double coin knot, the standing ends enter opposite long sides.
The next smallest possible basket weave knot is made up of a three–by–four rectangle, and may be called a [[boatswain]]'s lanyard, whistle lanyard, [[Napoleon Bonaparte|Napoleon]] knot, or Chinese knot,<ref name="ashley2"/> although the art of [[Chinese knotting]] includes many more knots besides this one.

[[File:Benefits Supervisor Sleeping.jpg|thumb|440px|''Benefits Supervisor Sleeping'', Lucian Freud, 1995.]] '''''Benefits Supervisor Sleeping''''' is a 1995 oil on canvas [[painting]] by [[Lucian Freud]] depicting an obese, naked woman lying on a couch. It is a [[portrait]] of [[Sue Tilley]], a Job Centre supervisor{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/11608941/I-didnt-set-out-to-be-Lucian-Freuds-muse.html|title=I didn't set out to be Lucian Freud's muse|last=Tilley|first=Sue|date=May 16, 2015|website=The Telegraph|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 21, 2018}}, then weighing about {{convert|127|kg|lb}}.{{cite news | url = http://www.centurion-magazine.com/home/art-and-culture/culture/portraits-of-an-artist.html | title = Portraits of an Artist | accessdate = 2014-03-12 | publisher = [[Centurion Magazine]] | date = 2012-01-12 | last = Hosea | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140318031211/http://www.centurion-magazine.com/home/art-and-culture/culture/portraits-of-an-artist.html | archivedate = 2014-03-18 | df = }} Tilley is the author of a biography of the Australian performer [[Leigh Bowery]] titled ''Leigh Bowery, The Life and Times of an Icon''. Tilley was introduced to Freud by Bowery, who was already modelling for him. Freud painted a number of large portraits of her around the period 1994–96, and came to call her "Big Sue". He said of her body "It's flesh without muscle and it has developed a different kind of texture through bearing such a weight-bearing thing".[[National Portrait Gallery, London|National Portrait Gallery]], Exhibition booklet for ''Lucian Freud Portraits'', 2012, Section VII The painting held the world record for the highest price paid for a painting by a living artist when it was sold by [[Guy Naggar]]http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/cbdd4f36-5529-11dd-ae9c-000077b07658.html#axzz3l3nusfDK for US$33.6 million (£17.2 million){{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7398949.stm | title = Freud work sets new world record | accessdate = 2008-05-14 | publisher = [[BBC Online]] | date=2008-05-14}} at [[Christie's]] in New York in May 2008 to [[Roman Abramovich]].{{cite news | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1981367/Roman-Abramovich-revealed-as-Freud-and-Bacon-buyer.html | title = Roman Abramovich 'revealed as Freud and Bacon buyer' | accessdate = 2008-05-18 | publisher = ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' | location = London | first = Stephen | last = Adams | date = 2008-05-18 }} Freud's painting ''Benefits Supervisor Resting'', sold for £35.8million ($56.2million) in 2015 after his death in 2011, replacing ''Benefits Supervisor Sleeping'' as the most expensive Freud painting sold at auction.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3082464/1994-Freud-titled-Benefits-Supervisor-Resting-sells-auction-35-8million.html|title=Benefits Supervisor Resting by Freud auctioned for £35.8million|work=Mail Online|access-date=2018-05-22}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.hull2017.co.uk/discover/article/lipstick-leigh-bowery-lucian-freuds-35m-muse/|title=Lipstick, Leigh Bowery and me… by Lucian Freud’s £35m muse – Hull UK City of Culture 2017|work=Hull UK City of Culture 2017|access-date=2017-07-25|language=en-US}}
The painting was exhibited twice at Flowers Gallery:
*1996: ''Naked'' – Flowers East at London Fields *1997: ''British Figurative Art - Part 1: Painting'' at Flowers East == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.christies.com/LotFinder/lot_details.aspx?intObjectID=5074074 Lot Details on Christies.com] {{Italic title}} {{Lucian Freud}} [[Category:Paintings by Lucian Freud]] [[Category:Nude art]] [[Category:1995 paintings]] [[Category:Portraits of women]] {{art-stub}}

[[File:Karnak Ajmenu Tutmosis III Sala Jardín Botánico 1.JPG|thumb|220px|A detail of the ''Botanical garden'']] '''The Botanical garden of Thutmose III''' ({{lang-fr|Jardin botanique de Thoutmôsis III}}) is an artistic representation of [[fauna]] and especially [[flora]] during the [[Egyptian empire]] at its peak. The remarkably detailed reliefs are located on the walls of the room next to the [[Festival Hall of Thutmose III]], in the [[Precinct of Amun-Re]], [[Karnak]].<ref name="Ratié1979">{{cite book|last=Ratié|first=Suzanne|title=La reine Hatchepsout: sources et problèmes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LWxZpn63tdMC&pg=PA151|accessdate=25 November 2011|year=1979|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-06064-7|page=151}}</ref> On land at the rear of the shrine, the [[Eighteenth dynasty of Egypt|18th dynasty]] Pharaoh [[Thutmose III]] built the Festival Hall of Thutmose III, also known as the ''Akh-menu''. The walls were then used by royal artists who, by order of the [[pharaoh]], engraved in stone some of the most beautiful pastoral representations of Egypt.
Thutmose III, the great warrior pharaoh who expanded the boundaries of Egypt in the north and the south, collected a considerable collection of rare species of animals and lush plants. His animals and botanical collection are found engraved on the walls of the sanctuary. Through the royal artists, the pharaoh boasts of the scenic beauty, the lush flora and rich fauna he discovered during his victorious campaigns against Asiatics.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Bibliography== *[[Nathalie Beaux-Grimal|Nathalie Beaux]], ''Le cabinet de curiosités de Thoutmosis III : plantes et animaux du « Jardin botanique » de Karnak'', Leuven, Peeters, coll. « Orientalia Lovaniensia Analecta » (no 36), 1990 ({{ISBN|9068312685}})

'''Business of Design Week''' (BODW) is an annual week-long design event organised every December by the [[Hong Kong Design Centre]]. BODW was launched in 2002. It includes a design conference, forums, exhibitions and award presentations.
Each Year BODW invites designers, business leaders and educators to speak and share their opinions in various forums. Past speakers include [[Marcel Wanders]], [[Rem Koolhaas]], [[Raman Hui]], [[Zaha Hadid]], [[Tom Dixon (industrial designer)]], [[Jimmy Choo]], [[John William Sorrell|Sir John Sorrell]], [[Karim Rashid]], [[Bingham Willis]], [[Marc Newson]], and [[Vivienne Tam]].
Each year, BODW forms a partnership with a different country. The country is invited to bring a group of designers to Hong Kong to give presentations at the conference. The country can also hold exhibitions and seminars about its national design. The partner country for 2008 was the [[Netherlands]] and for 2006 and 2007 was the [[UK]] and [[Italy]] respectively.
BODW has main events which occur each year including the BODW Forum where designers give presentations. There is also the HKDC Award Gala Dinner where the [[HKDC Awards]] are presented. These awards include the Design for Asia Awards, the World’s Outstanding Chinese Designer Award, the Design Leadership Award, the Design for Asia Award, and the Hong Kong Young Design Talent Awards.
